awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Effects of Ammonia on the Chemical and Physical Properties of Atmospheric Secondary Organic Aerosol
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the effects of ammonia on the chemical and physical properties of small particles in the atmosphere.  It will also look at the effects of ammonia on brown carbon in the atmosphere.  The approach will combine ambient measurements, 3-D chemical transport modeling, and the analysis of past field campaign data. This work will provide important insight into the sources and formation processes of secondary organic aerosol, critical for a better understanding of both air quality and climate.

The objectives of the proposal are to: (1) Characterize the effects of NH3 on the concentration and reversible/irreversible nature of aqueous SOA (aqSOA); (2) Characterize the effect of NH3 on atmospheric BrC formation; and (3) Determine the spatial and temporal scales of the NH3 impacts on aqSOA and BrC formation.  The two processes that will be evaluated include aqueous reactions that are either catalyzed by or directly involve NH4 and represent a significant source of highly oxidized, lower-volatility SOA, and the reaction of NH4 with organic compounds and the production of SOA that may be light-absorbing.

Ambient measurements will be made at an urban site in the eastern U.S. that is heavily influenced by biogenic VOC emissions, mobile sources, and regional NH3 emissions from agriculture.  Modeling studies, using WRF-CMAQ, will provide an analysis of temporal and spatial variability in the NH3 effects on SOA and BrC formation and the impacts on air quality and climate.

por.por_cntn:
The atmospheric burden of particulate matter adversely affects health, alters the fate and transport of trace species in the Earth system, and plays a role in regional radiative forcing. Most ambient particle mass forms during transport in the atmosphere from chemical reactions of precursor gases whose products partition, and this process is called secondary aerosol formation. Critical open questions surround the controlling chemistry that has a determining impact on secondary organic aerosol (SOA) mass and chemical composition, in particular for chemistry involving the predominant basic gas of the atmosphere, ammonia. In this work we conducted field, lab, and modeling experiments to gain insight into the fundamental chemistry of SOA formation and subsequent impacts. We disseminated results through publications in the peer-reviewed literature and through presentations at national meetings, often led by graduate students, an undergraduate student and postdoc. Broadly in support of this grant, we conducted atmospheric modeling to understand controlling factors on formation of SOA, field and lab experiments to understand the browning of SOA, and field experiments to understand atmospheric ammonia in the context of air quality tools and metrics. 

During the Southern Oxidant and Aerosol Study (SOAS), hundreds of gas- and particle- phase chemical species were quantified at high time resolution. This fostered substantial model development, especially for SOA formation mediated by aerosol liquid water. We conducted annual simulations of air quality over the contiguous U.S. using global and regional scale models developed and improved through comparison to SOAS findings. We quantified how SOA mass and chemical composition changes in response to perturbations in emissions of precursors, and find that most SOA mass, even when the precursor organic gas is derived from natural sources (e.g., plants, trees), forms due to controllable emissions from human activity. Previous air quality modeling informed by SOAS and focused on SOA formation via water-mediated chemistry exclusively studied the Southeast U.S. In our simulations of the entire contiguous U.S., we found that chemistry in aerosol liquid water occurs in arid regions as well. With a global model, we were able to reproduce decadal trends in secondary organic carbon across the U.S. in humid and arid regions alike.  

Ammonia and nitrogen-containing species are often associated with particle-phase "brown carbon," which has implications for climate-relevant aerosol properties. We conducted a series of lab and field experiments to investigate this process. In lab work we were able to reproduce the "browning" effect observed in earlier laboratory work by other research groups. However, in field work conducted at atmospherically relevant conditions, most notably, relative humidity above 30%, typical of eastern U.S., browning did not occur.   

Field measurements at Hart Miller Island, east of downtown Baltimore, demonstrated atmospheric ammonia concentrations much higher than recorded at nearby routine monitoring sites. We find that concentrations arise primarily from dairy farms, in addition to industrial sources that we are unable to discern from the National Emissions Inventory (NEI). There are implications for model findings based on poorly constrained ammonia emissions, which may be the case for U.S. bottom-up inventories.
